title: Arsenio Iglesias
text:
Arsenio Iglesias Pardo (born 24 December 1930) is a Spanish former <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> and <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>.
Nicknamed "O Bruxo de Arteixo" ("The Wizard of Arteixo"), his professional career, which spanned more than four decades, was closely associated to <a href="Deportivo%20de%20La%20Coru%C3%B1a">Deportivo</a> as both a player and manager.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Arteixo">Arteixo</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20A%20Coru%C3%B1a">Province of A Coruña</a>, Iglesias started his career with local side <a href="Deportivo%20de%20La%20Coru%C3%B1a">Deportivo de La Coruña</a>. He made his <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> debut on 28 October 1951 in a 6–1 away loss against <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a>, and scored the following weekend against <a href="RCD%20Espanyol">RCD Español</a> (3–1 home win).
Iglesias netted seven goals in three separate seasons for the <a href="Galicia%20%28Spain%29">Galicians</a>, adding a career-best eight in <a href="1956%E2%80%9357%20La%20Liga">1956–57</a>, which nonetheless ended in relegation. In six of the following eight years he also played in the top division, representing <a href="Sevilla%20FC">Sevilla FC</a>, <a href="Granada%20CF">Granada CF</a> and <a href="Real%20Oviedo">Real Oviedo</a>; he amassed competition totals of 238 games and 50 goals, and retired at 35 after a spell in the lower leagues with <a href="Albacete%20Balompi%C3%A9">Albacete Balompié</a>.
Coaching career.
Iglesias started coaching one year after retiring, his first appointment being at <a href="Deportivo%20Fabril">Deportivo's reserves</a>, which he accumulated with assistant duties in the main squad. Midway through the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">1970–71 campaign</a> he was named the first team's manager, leading them to a top-flight promotion and being <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20La%20Liga">relegated in 1973</a>.
In <a href="1973%E2%80%9374%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">1973–74</a>, Iglesias repeated the feat with another <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Segunda División</a> side, <a href="H%C3%A9rcules%20CF">Hércules CF</a>, then remained at the club's helm for a further three years, always managing to comfortably stay afloat – this included a <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20La%20Liga">fifth place in 1975</a> and <a href="1975%E2%80%9376%20La%20Liga">a sixth in 1976</a>. In the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">1977–78 season</a> another promotion to the main division befell, this time as champions with <a href="Real%20Zaragoza">Real Zaragoza</a>.
Iglesias worked in the top tier in two of the next three seasons, leading <a href="Burgos%20CF">Burgos CF</a> to the 13th position in <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20La%20Liga">1978–79</a> and being fired by <a href="AD%20Almer%C3%ADa">AD Almería</a> midway through the <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20La%20Liga">1980–81 campaign</a> amid several internal disputes. In 1982 he returned to Deportivo, with the club in division two.
In <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">1987–88</a>, Iglesias was one of three coaches as "Depor" nearly suffered relegation to <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">Segunda División B</a>, being saved by a <a href="last-minute%20goal">last-minute goal</a> against <a href="Racing%20de%20Santander">Racing de Santander</a>. He was again reinstated as first-team manager, finally attaining promotion to the first division in <a href="1990%E2%80%9391%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">1991</a> after ranking second.
Iglesias replaced the dismissed Marco Antonio Boronat at the club's helm late in <a href="1991%E2%80%9392%20La%20Liga">1991–92</a>, as Deportivo had to play a <a href="Promotion%20and%20relegation">relegation playoff</a> against <a href="Real%20Betis">Real Betis</a>, eventually winning 2–1 on aggregate. In the following seasons, however, "Super Depor" came to fruition, with several team players winning individual accolades and being called to the <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">Spain national team</a> as the side finished three consecutive campaigns in the top three; during this timeframe, he was named Manager of the Year three times, twice by <a href="Don%20Bal%C3%B3n">Don Balón</a> and once by <a href="El%20Pa%C3%ADs">El País</a>.
Iglesias retired from football after <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20La%20Liga">1994–95</a>. Midway through <a href="1995%E2%80%9396%20La%20Liga">the following campaign</a>, however, he accepted an offer from <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a> to replace fired <a href="Jorge%20Valdano">Jorge Valdano</a>, with the "Merengues" finally ranking sixth and <a href="1995%E2%80%9396%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">being eliminated in the quarter-finals</a> of the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> by eventual winners <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus FC</a>.
In 2005, Iglesias was appointed manager of the <a href="Galicia%20official%20football%20team">Galicia autonomous football team</a>, working alongside <a href="Fernando%20V%C3%A1zquez">Fernando Vázquez</a>. In the previous decade, he also worked as a <a href="sports%20commentator">sports commentator</a>.
In 2016, Iglesias was bestowed with the highest recognition of Deportivo, a special insignia, and was declared "Blue and White Legend". The event took place at halftime of the last game of the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20La%20Liga">2015–16 season</a>, at the "<a href="Estadio%20Riazor">Estadio Riazor</a>".
